title.value: LEARNING ON LARGE-SCALE TEXT-ATTRIBUTED GRAPHS VIA VARIATIONAL INFERENCE
title.justification: This is the official title of the paper as given at the top.
title.quote: LEARNING ON LARGE-SCALE TEXT-ATTRIBUTED GRAPHS VIA VARIATIONAL INFERENCE

extractions.description: This paper tackles the problem of learning on large text-attributed graphs, where each node is associated with a text description. The authors propose an efficient and effective approach called GLEM, which fuses graph structure and language learning using a variational Expectation-Maximization framework. This method alternates between updating language models and graph neural networks to achieve improved scalability and effectiveness.

type.justification: The paper includes extensive experiments and evaluations across multiple datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed approach, GLEM.
type.quote: Extensive experiments on multiple data sets demonstrate the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed approach

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on learning representations for nodes in text-attributed graphs, combining both graph structures and textual information.
name.quote: This paper studies learning on text-attributed graphs (TAGs)...

name.justification: The paper involves processing and leveraging textual information associated with nodes in the graphs, which falls under the domain of NLP.
name.quote: each node is associated with a text description... leveraging large language models

name.justification: The paper discusses various methods and models related to graph neural networks, which are used for learning from the graph structure.
name.quote: structural relationships could be effectively modeled by a graph neural network (GNN) via the message-passing mechanism.

name.justification: The method proposed in the paper leverages a variational Expectation-Maximization framework for model training.
name.quote: fuses graph structure and language learning with a variational Expectation-Maximization (EM) framework

name.justification: GLEM is the primary model proposed by the authors to learn on large-scale text-attributed graphs using a variational EM framework.
name.quote: propose an efficient and effective solution to learning on large text-attributed graphs by fusing graph structure and language learning with a variational Expectation-Maximization (EM) framework, called GLEM.

is_contributed.justification: GLEM is the main contribution of the research paper.
is_contributed.quote: propose an efficient and effective solution to learning on large text-attributed graphs...called GLEM.

is_executed.justification: Extensive experiments were conducted to evaluate the performance of GLEM, indicating it was executed during the course of this research.
is_executed.quote: Extensive experiments on multiple data sets demonstrate the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed approach

is_compared.justification: The paper compares GLEM with various existing models to demonstrate its superior performance.
is_compared.quote: GLEM achieves new state-of-the-art results on ogbn-arxiv, ogbn-product, and ogbn-papers100M.

referenced_paper_title.justification: GLEM is introduced as a novel model in this paper and does not reference a previous paper specifically related to it.

name.justification: This dataset is used in the paper to evaluate the performance of GLEM.
name.quote: GLEM achieves new state-of-the-art results on ogbn-arxiv

referenced_paper_title.value: Open Graph Benchmark: Datasets for Machine Learning on Graphs
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset ogbn-arxiv is part of the Open Graph Benchmark (OGB) datasets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Three TAG node classification benchmarks are used in our experiment, including ogbn-arxiv... (Hu et al., 2020).

name.justification: PyTorch is used for implementing GLEM as inferred from the related work and methods sections.

referenced_paper_title.justification: PyTorch is commonly used for automatic differentiation in implementing neural networks and was likely referenced in this work.
